source.name: Ville de Montréal
source.notes: Based on official Ville de Montréal recycling guidelines. Standardized Quebec-wide list as of Jan 2025: only containers, packaging, and printed materials. Brown bin for organics.

materials.name: Plastic bottles
instructions: Place in recycling bin (blue or green Bac Impact)
notes: All numbered plastic containers and packaging accepted under Quebec standardized list (Jan 2025)
commonMistakes: Don't include bottles with liquid in them

materials.name: Plastic tubs and containers
notes: All numbered plastic containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't nest items inside each other

materials.name: Plastic clamshells and trays
notes: Clear and coloured clamshells accepted as packaging

materials.name: Plastic bags and film
instructions: Stuff all flexible plastic bags/film inside one bag and tie shut
notes: Quebec standardized list includes flexible plastic packaging
Bundle bags together so they don't scatter
commonMistakes: Don't leave loose; stuff into one bag and tie
Don't include non-packaging plastic film (e.g., tarps, pool covers)

materials.name: Foam / styrofoam packaging
instructions: Must be packaging or food-related foam
notes: Quebec standardized list includes foam packaging
commonMistakes: Don't include non-packaging foam (e.g., insulation, craft foam)

materials.name: Metal food cans
notes: Metal containers/packaging accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include cans with food residue

materials.name: Beverage cans
notes: Aluminum is infinitely recyclable
Deposit refund at consigne locations

materials.name: Aluminum foil
instructions: Ball up into a ball at least the size of a golf ball
notes: Must ball up foil so it doesn't slip through sorting screens
commonMistakes: Must be balled up, not flat

materials.name: Aluminum trays and pie plates
notes: Aluminum packaging accepted

materials.name: Empty aerosol cans
notes: Metal packaging accepted; must be fully depressurized
commonMistakes: Don't recycle if still pressurized; take to ecocentre

materials.name: Glass bottles and jars
notes: Glass containers accepted as packaging
Remove lids from large-mouth jars (small caps can stay)
commonMistakes: Don't include broken glass; wrap and put in garbage
Don't include window glass, mirrors, drinking glasses, or ceramics

materials.name: Cardboard
instructions: Place in or beside recycling bin
notes: Lid of recycling bin must still close; large cardboard can be placed beside
commonMistakes: Food-soiled cardboard goes in brown bin

materials.name: Paperboard boxes
instructions: Flatten and place in recycling bin
notes: Thin cardboard/paperboard is recyclable as packaging

materials.name: Newspapers
notes: Printed materials accepted

materials.name: Magazines and catalogues
notes: Printed materials accepted

materials.name: Office paper and mail
notes: Printed materials and paper packaging accepted

materials.name: Paper bags
instructions: Flatten and place in recycling bin
notes: Paper packaging accepted
commonMistakes: Food-soiled bags go in brown bin

materials.name: Milk and juice cartons
notes: Cartons are accepted as packaging

materials.name: Egg cartons
instructions: Paper, cardboard, and foam egg cartons all go in recycling bin
notes: All egg carton types accepted as packaging in Montreal

materials.name: Books
instructions: Damaged books: place in recycling bin
notes: Printed materials accepted
commonMistakes: Don't throw usable books in garbage

materials.name: Metal lids and caps
instructions: Small caps on bottles can stay on
Place loose lids in recycling bin
notes: Except for small caps, remove lids from containers per Montreal guidelines
commonMistakes: Don't leave lids on large-mouth containers

materials.name: Non-packaging plastic objects
instructions: Non-packaging plastics NOT accepted in recycling
notes: As of Jan 2025 Quebec standardized list: ONLY containers, packaging, and printed materials are accepted
Plastic objects that are not packaging go in garbage
commonMistakes: Don't put plastic toys, furniture, or non-packaging items in recycling

materials.name: Non-packaging metal objects
instructions: Place in garbage or take to ecocentre
Non-packaging metal NOT accepted in recycling bin
notes: Only metal packaging/containers accepted in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put pots, pans, or metal objects in recycling bin

materials.name: Non-packaging glass objects
instructions: Wrap safely and place in garbage
Non-packaging glass NOT accepted in recycling
notes: Only glass bottles/jars (packaging) go in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put mirrors, ceramics, or drinking glasses in recycling

materials.name: Food waste (all types)
instructions: All food accepted: meat, dairy, bones, fish, fruit, vegetables
Use paper bag or newspaper as liner
notes: Montreal brown bin collects organic waste weekly
commonMistakes: Don't use plastic bags as liners

materials.name: Fruit and fruit scraps
notes: All fruit scraps go in brown bin

materials.name: Vegetables and vegetable scraps
notes: All vegetable scraps go in brown bin

materials.name: Meat and bones
instructions: Wrap in newspaper or paper bag
notes: Montreal brown bin accepts all meat and bones

materials.name: Dairy products
notes: Expired dairy food goes in brown bin

materials.name: Bread and grains
notes: All grain-based food waste goes in brown bin

materials.name: Eggs and eggshells
notes: Eggshells are compostable

materials.name: Coffee grounds and filters
instructions: Paper filters and tea bags included
notes: Great compost material
commonMistakes: Remove staples from tea bags if present

materials.name: Food-soiled paper
notes: Food-soiled paper goes with organics, not recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put soiled paper in recycling bin

materials.name: Yard waste
instructions: Place in brown bin or yard waste bags
notes: Yard waste collection may be seasonal; check montreal.ca

materials.name: Chip bags and snack pouches
notes: The metallic lining prevents recycling

materials.name: Candy wrappers
notes: Mixed metallized film; not recyclable

materials.name: Receipts (thermal)
notes: Non-thermal paper receipts can go in recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put thermal receipts in recycling

materials.name: Diapers
notes: Not compostable in Montreal's program

materials.name: Pet waste
notes: Not accepted in brown bin

materials.name: Plastic cutlery
notes: Non-packaging plastic; not accepted in recycling

materials.name: Plastic straws
notes: Non-packaging plastic

materials.name: Compostable plastics
instructions: NOT accepted in recycling or brown bin
notes: Compostable plastics contaminate both recycling and organic streams
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling bin or brown bin

materials.name: Wax paper and parchment paper
notes: Wax coating prevents recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put in recycling or brown bin

materials.name: Batteries
instructions: Call-2-Recycle drop-off at many retailers (Canadian Tire, Home Depot, RONA)
Tape terminals of lithium and 9V batteries
notes: Never put batteries in garbage; they cause fires
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage or recycling

materials.name: Electronics / E-waste
notes: Quebec has electronics recycling regulation
Free drop-off at ecocentres
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage or recycling

materials.name: Paint
instructions: Éco-peinture program accepts leftover paint for free at participating retailers
notes: Do not pour down drain
commonMistakes: Don't pour down drain or put in garbage

materials.name: Medications
instructions: Jean Coutu, Pharmaprix/Shoppers Drug Mart accept medications
notes: Free take-back at pharmacies

materials.name: Clothing and textiles
instructions: Donate to Renaissance, Village des Valeurs/Value Village, or Salvation Army
notes: Worn-out textiles also accepted at some bins
commonMistakes: Don't put in garbage if reusable

materials.name: Light bulbs
instructions: CFL and fluorescent: take to ecocentre or participating retailer
LED and incandescent: wrap and garbage
notes: CFL bulbs contain mercury; RecycFluo program handles collection
commonMistakes: Don't put CFL or fluorescent in garbage

materials.name: Motor oil
instructions: Take to ecocentre or auto parts store
SOGHU program handles used oil recycling in Quebec
notes: Never pour down drain

materials.name: Propane tanks
notes: Pressurized containers are dangerous in garbage
commonMistakes: Never puncture or put in garbage

materials.name: Needles and sharps
instructions: Take to a pharmacy or CLSC
notes: Never put loose sharps in any bin
commonMistakes: Never put in garbage or recycling

materials.name: Mattress
instructions: Schedule a large item pickup through 311
notes: Large item curbside pickup available by request
commonMistakes: Don't leave at curb without scheduling

materials.name: Tires
instructions: Take to a tire retailer or ecocentre
Most shops accept old tires with purchase
notes: Recyc-Québec manages tire recycling

materials.name: Cooking oil and grease
instructions: Small amounts: pour onto newspaper and place in brown bin
notes: Never pour down the drain

materials.name: Pizza box
instructions: If heavily soiled with grease: brown bin
notes: Greasy cardboard contaminates paper recycling
commonMistakes: Don't put greasy boxes in recycling bin

materials.name: Spray bottles (plastic)
notes: Plastic packaging containers accepted
commonMistakes: Don't include if it held hazardous material

materials.name: Disposable coffee cups (paper, lined)
instructions: Lined paper cups are not accepted in Montreal curbside recycling
notes: The plastic/wax lining prevents recycling
Plastic lid can go in recycling bin

materials.name: Toothbrush
notes: Non-packaging plastic object; not recyclable

materials.name: Smartphone / phone
instructions: Take to ecocentre or carrier store
notes: Free recycling at ecocentres

materials.name: Chargers and cables
instructions: Take to ecocentre or electronics retailer
notes: Cables tangle in recycling machinery

materials.name: Fluorescent tubes
instructions: Take to ecocentre or RecycFluo drop-off (RONA, Home Depot)
notes: Contains mercury; handle carefully

recycle: All numbered plastic containers and packaging
Plastic bags and film (bundled in one bag)
Spray bottles and household plastic containers
compost: All food waste (meat, dairy, bones, fruit, vegetables)
Food-soiled paper (pizza boxes, napkins, paper towels)
trash: Non-packaging plastic objects (toys, buckets, lawn chairs)

recycle: Non-packaging plastic, metal, or glass objects
Chip bags and metallized film wrappers

tips: As of Jan 2025: Quebec standardized list — ONLY containers, packaging, and printed materials accepted in recycling
Non-packaging objects (toys, pots, mirrors) go in GARBAGE even if made of recyclable material
Plastic bags/film: stuff all into one bag and tie shut before placing in recycling bin
Ball up aluminum foil to at least golf-ball size
Remove lids from large-mouth jars/pots (small caps can stay on bottles)
Don't nest items inside each other in the recycling bin
Lid of recycling bin must close; flatten cardboard
Brown bin for all food waste and food-soiled paper

locations.name: Ecocentres (Ville de Montréal)
locations.notes: 8 ecocentres across Montreal; check website for nearest location and hours. Free for Montreal residents.

locations.name: Info-collectes (311)
locations.notes: Call 311 or use the Info-collectes tool online for schedules and special pickups
